title: Two Research Vessels' Mission
description:
Phytoplankton...tiny, mostly single-celled organisms that live in the oceans, creating energy for our ocean's ecosystems.
They're eaten by zooplankton, slightly larger organisms that make a daily trek from the ocean's sunny upper layer to its pitch-black depths.
In this cycle, they drift through an important region, 
a dimly lit middle ground between light and shadow...an area scientists call the twilight zone.
Enter the Export Processes in the Ocean from Remote Sensing, or EXPORTS project
a team of more than 150 scientists... from 29 different institutions...
onboard two research vessels with a fleet of autonomous vehicles...

title: Hurricanes and Aerosols Impact
description: This visualization shows how NASA uses satellite data and physics to track aerosols like dust, smoke, and sea salt in the atmosphere. Sea salt, carried by winds over the oceans, forms spirals during storms like Hurricane Irma, while Saharan dust is drawn out by rain. Advances in computing help scientists create more detailed simulations, showing how aerosols interact with storm systems and improving weather predictions. A unique example is Hurricane Ophelia, which carried dust from the Sahara and smoke from Portugal all the way to Ireland and the UK, a rare event that highlights the complex interactions between aerosols and weather

title: NASA Aerosols Study
description: Aerosols are particles or droplets in the atmosphere. Their chemical and physical properties can have significant influences on climate and Earth's energy budget. PACE will help monitor aerosols in the atmosphere

title: Ocean's Role in Food Security
description: Ocean health matters in terms of maintaining global fisheries. Fisheries are enormous sources of food for populations all over the world. PACE will be able to make measurements in a number of areas that will contribute to fisheries management, which is vital for food security

title: Tracking Red Tide
description:
Red tides can come from harmful algal blooms near shore for a variety of reasons. PACE will help scientists monitor red tides.
NASA missions monitor the ocean from space to protect fisheries and human health. The detection of harmful algal blooms, like red tides, will help us avoid their negative impacts

title: S2S Instruments: Ocean Tech
description: Field sketching on a boat is challenging, but the equipment used makes it worthwhile. Scientists are studying the carbon cycle by measuring oxygen production and consumption with a photosynthetron, simulating different light conditions. They also use instruments like a laser to analyze particle sizes and a wire walker to measure water properties such as temperature and salinity. A holographic camera captures particle data, later analyzed in virtual reality. While new technologies carry risks, traditional methods ensure reliable measurements if needed

title: Phytopia: Ocean Micro-Life
description:
Phytoplankton are tiny plants and algae that live in the upper sunlit layer of almost all water bodies on Earth. Powered by the sun's energy, they come in many shapes and sizes. They serve as the base of the marine food web, and produce oxygen vital to life. Studying this incredibly diverse group is key to understanding the health - and future - of our ocean and life on earth. PACE's advanced ocean color technology is designed to help to distinguish 'who's who' in terms of phytoplankton communities.
Phytopia
Phytopia lets you explore the fascinating world of phytoplankton. The tool uses concept maps — which highlight connections — to display complex information. Use Phytopia to learn about the roles these plankton play in the ecosystem, whether they are harmful or not... or just explore the beauty of these tiny titans

url.title: PhytoInsta: Phytoplankton Images
url.description: NASA researchers found, during the last 15 years, populations of microscopic marine plants called phytoplankton, have decreased in the Northern Hemisphere. If this declining trend, in phytoplankton levels, continues it could affect the entire marine food web.

url.title: Decline of Microscopic Organisms
url.description: Diatoms, a key type of marine phytoplankton, have shown a global decline over 15 years, according to a NASA study. These organisms need sunlight and nutrients like nitrate and iron to thrive at the ocean's surface. However, changes in how nutrients cycle in the water column, especially in the Northern Hemisphere, have reduced their availability. This leads to fewer nutrients reaching the diatoms, causing population declines. Scientists are still studying the reasons behind these changes, which may be linked to factors like wind, ocean circulation, and temperature

url.title: Oceans' Green Machine
url.description: From space, Earth is clearly an ocean planet. Although the ocean may seem empty from the shore, beneath the surface it teems with microscopic plants called phytoplankton. These tiny organisms are crucial to life on Earth, forming the base of the marine food web and producing half of the planet's oxygen through photosynthesis. Researchers track phytoplankton from space using satellites that monitor ocean color, allowing them to observe global changes. As ocean temperatures rise, phytoplankton levels have decreased, impacting marine ecosystems. Understanding these changes is vital for studying Earth's climate and the interconnectedness of global systems
